Changeling & Inquisitor

1.Inquisitor: Poor child... I was all indignation just a moment ago, but I feel only pity now. The things that happen in this land! Another victim of those deceiving bastards... Don't you know miracles are impossible?

1.Inquisitor: Poor child... I was all indignation just a moment ago, but I feel only pity now. The things that happen in this land! Another victim of those deceiving bastards... Don't you know miracles are impossible?

2.Changeling: Who's deceiving me? Do you mean the Saburovs?

2.Changeling: Who's deceiving me? Do you mean the Saburovs?

3.Inquisitor: No. The Powers That Be. They deceived you, like they did everyone else. The Saburovs are also victims of their scheming. They, the Saburovs, wanted to use you to strike at the disease carrier. But you shouldn't have killed anyone. No member of the Circle is to blame for the outbreak. The logic of the world is. Such is the Law.

3.Inquisitor: No. The Powers That Be. They deceived you, like they did everyone else. The Saburovs are also victims of their scheming. They, the Saburovs, wanted to use you to strike at the disease carrier. But you shouldn't have killed anyone. No member of the Circle is to blame for the outbreak. The logic of the world is. Such is the Law.

4.Changeling: The Powers That Be could not have deceived me. I know what they're really worth.

4.Changeling: The Powers That Be could not have deceived me. I know what they're really worth.

5.Inquisitor: Miracles violate the world; they're abusive in nature. When the world was conceived, it was conceived as a coherent whole, without contradictions. Harmony is the main, indeed the only component of any Universe. However ugly a world may be, however unfair it may seem-it is nonetheless harmonious!

5.Inquisitor: Miracles violate the world; they're abusive in nature. When the world was conceived, it was conceived as a coherent whole, without contradictions. Harmony is the main, indeed the only component of any Universe. However ugly a world may be, however unfair it may seem-it is nonetheless harmonious!

6.Changeling: Look around you! Or is this what you call harmony?

6.Changeling: Look around you! Or is this what you call harmony?

7.Inquisitor: Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?

7.Inquisitor: Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?

8.Changeling: I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!

8.Changeling: I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!

9.Inquisitor: And who do you think you are, daring to interfere in a supreme design? What could the consequences be of your meaningless actions?

9.Inquisitor: And who do you think you are, daring to interfere in a supreme design? What could the consequences be of your meaningless actions?

10.Changeling: I...

10.Changeling: I...

11.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

11.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

12.Changeling: You...

12.Changeling: You...

13.Inquisitor: And yet I hope that you're highly overrating yourself. There's a different account of the same events, isn't there? Equally convincing arguments have been put forward in support of the claim that you are disease incarnate-its personification, such as have been known throughout history.

13.Inquisitor: And yet I hope that you're highly overrating yourself. There's a different account of the same events, isn't there? Equally convincing arguments have been put forward in support of the claim that you are disease incarnate-its personification, such as have been known throughout history.

14.Changeling: That's not what I am!

14.Changeling: That's not what I am!

15.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

15.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

16.Changeling: ...I made the sister up. I never had one.

16.Changeling: ...I made the sister up. I never had one.

17.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

17.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

22.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

22.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

23.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

23.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

24.Changeling: Yes, we have things to talk about...

24.Changeling: Yes, we have things to talk about...

25.Inquisitor: And mind you, I need you here with a report before the end of today! Or else I'll kill you.

25.Inquisitor: And mind you, I need you here with a report before the end of today! Or else I'll kill you.

26.Changeling: What have I ever done to you?

26.Changeling: What have I ever done to you?

27.Inquisitor: I've been sent here to smother the disease and reinstate the Law. Plague or miracle-worker, in my eyes you're a menace either way. I won't go soft on you. Remember, I'm keeping you on a long leash.

27.Inquisitor: I've been sent here to smother the disease and reinstate the Law. Plague or miracle-worker, in my eyes you're a menace either way. I won't go soft on you. Remember, I'm keeping you on a long leash.

28.Changeling: All right. I'll do as you say...

28.Changeling: All right. I'll do as you say...

28.Changeling: I'll visit them to look into their eyes again. But I'll come back with my own verdict, same as back then! And you'll defer to it! That is what you've decided yourself...

28.Changeling: I'll visit them to look into their eyes again. But I'll come back with my own verdict, same as back then! And you'll defer to it! That is what you've decided yourself...

24.Changeling: I won't! They're my mother and father...

24.Changeling: I won't! They're my mother and father...

25.Inquisitor: Oh yes you will. Have they not betrayed you? Have they not disowned you? Have they not thrown you out of the house they had told you earlier to call your own? Some parents! Don't deny it. I know everything.

25.Inquisitor: Oh yes you will. Have they not betrayed you? Have they not disowned you? Have they not thrown you out of the house they had told you earlier to call your own? Some parents! Don't deny it. I know everything.

26.Changeling: You're leaving me no choice...

26.Changeling: You're leaving me no choice...

27.Inquisitor: And mind you, I need you here with a report before the end of today! Or else I'll kill you.

27.Inquisitor: And mind you, I need you here with a report before the end of today! Or else I'll kill you.

28.Changeling: What have I ever done to you?

28.Changeling: What have I ever done to you?

29.Inquisitor: I've been sent here to smother the disease and reinstate the Law. Plague or miracle-worker, in my eyes you're a menace either way. I won't go soft on you. Remember, I'm keeping you on a long leash.

29.Inquisitor: I've been sent here to smother the disease and reinstate the Law. Plague or miracle-worker, in my eyes you're a menace either way. I won't go soft on you. Remember, I'm keeping you on a long leash.

30.Changeling: All right. I'll do as you say...

30.Changeling: All right. I'll do as you say...

30.Changeling: I'll visit them to look into their eyes again. But I'll come back with my own verdict, same as back then! And you'll defer to it! That is what you've decided yourself...

16.Changeling: Alone? I'm not sure of that...

12.Changeling: I didn't give myself that prerogative! Or are you already putting me on trial as a thief, to be hanged alongside robbers and looters?

12.Changeling: I didn't give myself that prerogative! Or are you already putting me on trial as a thief, to be hanged alongside robbers and looters?

13.Inquisitor: I'll tell you why you're a thief later. I just need to see you in action first, so that I could finally convince myself.

13.Inquisitor: I'll tell you why you're a thief later. I just need to see you in action first, so that I could finally convince myself.

14.Changeling: Did the Bachelor inform on me? Did he say that I'm the personification of the disease? But that's not true!

14.Changeling: Did the Bachelor inform on me? Did he say that I'm the personification of the disease? But that's not true!

21.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

23.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

23.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

17.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

9.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

17.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

19.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

20.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

21.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

15.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

16.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

17.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

19.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

30.Changeling: I'll visit them to look into their eyes again. But I'll come back with my own verdict, same as back then! And you'll defer to it! That is what you've decided yourself...

4.Changeling: No, no... Somehow I feel it's not what's going to happen to me! I don't want to get my own back on the Powers! I can sense how weak they are... I'm sorry for them.

4.Changeling: No, no... Somehow I feel it's not what's going to happen to me! I don't want to get my own back on the Powers! I can sense how weak they are... I'm sorry for them.

5.Inquisitor: Shut up and listen to me. Did they want miracles from you?

5.Inquisitor: Shut up and listen to me. Did they want miracles from you?

6.Changeling: Yes... Three days ago I received a letter...

6.Changeling: Yes... Three days ago I received a letter...

7.Inquisitor: Miracles violate the world; they're abusive in nature. When the world was conceived, it was conceived as a coherent whole, without contradictions. Harmony is the main, indeed the only component of any Universe. However ugly a world may be, however unfair it may seem-it is nonetheless harmonious!

7.Inquisitor: Miracles violate the world; they're abusive in nature. When the world was conceived, it was conceived as a coherent whole, without contradictions. Harmony is the main, indeed the only component of any Universe. However ugly a world may be, however unfair it may seem-it is nonetheless harmonious!

8.Changeling: Look around you! Or is this what you call harmony?

8.Changeling: Look around you! Or is this what you call harmony?

9.Inquisitor: Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?

9.Inquisitor: Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?

10.Changeling: I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!

10.Changeling: I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!

11.Inquisitor: And who do you think you are, daring to interfere in a supreme design? What could the consequences be of your meaningless actions?

11.Inquisitor: And who do you think you are, daring to interfere in a supreme design? What could the consequences be of your meaningless actions?

12.Changeling: I...

12.Changeling: I...

13.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

13.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

14.Changeling: You...

14.Changeling: You...

15.Inquisitor: And yet I hope that you're highly overrating yourself. There's a different account of the same events, isn't there? Equally convincing arguments have been put forward in support of the claim that you are disease incarnate-its personification, such as have been known throughout history.

16.Changeling: That's not what I am!

16.Changeling: That's not what I am!

17.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

17.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

18.Changeling: ...I made the sister up. I never had one.

18.Changeling: ...I made the sister up. I never had one.

19.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

19.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

20.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

20.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

21.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

21.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! 22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

23.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

24.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

24.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

25.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

16.Changeling: In due time, inquisitor, I'll be the one judging you. Then you'll see what my kind of justice is like.

16.Changeling: In due time, inquisitor, I'll be the one judging you. Then you'll see what my kind of justice is like.

17.Inquisitor: And yet I hope that you're highly overrating yourself. There's a different account of the same events, isn't there? 23.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

25.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

20.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

21.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

21.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

23.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

23.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. 24.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

24.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

25.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

32.Changeling: All right. I'll do as you say...

18.Changeling: Alone? I'm not sure of that...

19.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

20.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

20.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

21.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

22.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

23.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

25.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

11.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

23.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

24.Changeling: I won't! They're my mother and father...

25.Inquisitor: Oh yes you will. Have they not betrayed you? Have they not disowned you? Have they not thrown you out of the house they had told you earlier to call your own? Some parents! Don't deny it. I know everything.

15.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

16.Changeling: ...I made the sister up. I never had one.

17.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. 20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

2.Changeling: Possibly.

2.Changeling: Possibly.

3.Inquisitor: Miracles violate the world; they're abusive in nature. When the world was conceived, it was conceived as a coherent whole, without contradictions. Harmony is the main, indeed the only component of any Universe. However ugly a world may be, however unfair it may seem-it is nonetheless harmonious!

3.Inquisitor: Miracles violate the world; they're abusive in nature. When the world was conceived, it was conceived as a coherent whole, without contradictions. Harmony is the main, indeed the only component of any Universe. However ugly a world may be, however unfair it may seem-it is nonetheless harmonious!

4.Changeling: Look around you! Or is this what you call harmony?

4.Changeling: Look around you! Or is this what you call harmony?

5.Inquisitor: Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?

5.Inquisitor: Of course I do! Or do you suppose harmony is the same as beauty, you dim pathetic creature?

6.Changeling: I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!

6.Changeling: I'm not talking about beauty... I'm talking about the miracle of salvation!

7.Inquisitor: And who do you think you are, daring to interfere in a supreme design? What could the consequences be of your meaningless actions?

7.Inquisitor: And who do you think you are, daring to interfere in a supreme design? What could the consequences be of your meaningless actions?

8.Changeling: I...

8.Changeling: I...

9.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

9.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

10.Changeling: You...

10.Changeling: You...

11.Inquisitor: And yet I hope that you're highly overrating yourself. There's a different account of the same events, isn't there? Equally convincing arguments have been put forward in support of the claim that you are disease incarnate-its personification, such as have been known throughout history.

12.Changeling: That's not what I am!

13.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

14.Changeling: ...I made the sister up. I never had one.

15.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

16.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

16.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

17.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

19.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

14.Changeling: That's not what I am!

15.Inquisitor: I know, I know, that's your sister. A twin, right? And an identical one. Impossible to tell apart from you. I wonder why I'm not seeing double like the others; why have you come here alone?

18.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

19.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

20.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

21.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

19.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

19.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

20.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

20.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

21.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

21.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

14.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

15.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

16.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

17.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

14.Changeling: Alone? I'm not sure of that...

15.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

15.Inquisitor: My oh my... You know what, tell me about your past, girl. Who are your mother and father, where are you from? What did you do before you came here? Who saw you on your way?

16.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

16.Changeling: ...I can't. I don't know who's acting under my guise right now. I can only feel their hands.

17.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

18.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

19.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

21.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

7.Inquisitor: Driven by either compassion or anger, you've had the audacity to tamper crudely with the finest fabric of creation, severing and rebinding threads that aren't for you to sever or rebind, it being the prerogative of a thousandfold greater mind than all of our paltry ones combined!

I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

17.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. 18.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

18.Changeling: ...What does that mean?

19.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

19.Inquisitor: You'll begin with the Saburovs. Do to them what they made you do to their subjects! Ask them. Find out how guilty they themselves think they are. True culprits are better than others at avoiding taking responsibility.

17.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

15.Inquisitor: ...So you won't tell? Then I will. You are insane, my child. Deranged. You have a split personality disorder. Schizophrenia, perhaps. What you think of as reality is sometimes replaced by an illusion, to reappear in its true vivid fullness later. A nice version, isn't it? An all-round nice one! The only thing it can't explain is your still being alive...

16.Changeling: ...So what am I to do?

17.Inquisitor: I'll make up my mind by this evening, and that's if I like you. For now, you'll do what I tell you to. I'd like to see you alter the fabric of creation-or more exactly, I'd like to convince myself that you can do nothing of the sort; that you're a mere changeling rather than someone who incites the change.

3.Inquisitor: Go ahead and ask. As you can see, I'm being very nice to you for now. Not merely satisfying your curiosity, but going as far as to try and preempt it.

3.Inquisitor: Go ahead and ask. As you can see, I'm being very nice to you for now. Not merely satisfying your curiosity, but going as far as to try and preempt it.

4.Changeling: Why am I being hounded as a thief? What does it mean?

4.Changeling: Why am I being hounded as a thief? What does it mean?

5.Inquisitor: It means that this is your nature. It means that this is your preordainment. As to what exactly it is that you've stolen... that's just the question I'm trying to find the answer to. What kind of a theft can possibly upturn the very foundations of existence? It's no wonder that the Law is after you. You are a great criminal indeed.

5.Inquisitor: It means that this is your nature. It means that this is your preordainment. As to what exactly it is that you've stolen... that's just the question I'm trying to find the answer to. 6.Changeling: ...Is that why my Bound are, by and large, all criminals?

6.Changeling: ...Is that why my Bound are, by and large, all criminals?

7.Inquisitor: Your Bound are no mere criminals; they're wicked to a rare degree. That is because they've broken the Law. They are to blame for all the evil that has flooded the world.

7.Inquisitor: Your Bound are no mere criminals; they're wicked to a rare degree. That is because they've broken the Law. They are to blame for all the evil that has flooded the world.

8.Changeling: But is anyone who breaks it necessarily a monster and a fiend? I'm talking about myself here!

8.Changeling: But is anyone who breaks it necessarily a monster and a fiend? I'm talking about myself here!

9.Inquisitor: We're inherently evil, Clara. Evil is what defines human nature. An attempt at self-discovery is a provocation. Don't make the mistake that your doomed counterparts are making now. Stand down.

9.Inquisitor: We're inherently evil, Clara. Evil is what defines human nature. An attempt at self-discovery is a provocation. Don't make the mistake that your doomed counterparts are making now. Stand down.

10.Changeling: The Bachelor and the Haruspex? How are they my counterparts?

10.Changeling: The Bachelor and the Haruspex? How are they my counterparts?

11.Inquisitor: Yes, they're hopeless. The issue is moot in their case. They never had an alternative-having never reached that degree of complexity. While you've had the misfortune to reach it, and that is your curse. Stand down before it's too late. What they can be forgiven for, you can't be.

12.Changeling: No! I won't leave. I'm staying.

13.Inquisitor: You still have time. I'm going to use you in my experiments. You see, I know who we all really are-while some, including your counterparts, don't know yet... I'm going to watch you tread the same path. And if I'm guessing correctly, and you really have those abilities... this place won't forgive you for it. And neither will I.

4.Changeling: Is he not human?

5.Inquisitor: An equal blend of human and beast. As I understood from esteemed Bos Olgimsky's account, his father had been begotten on a Steppe woman by a bull. He is thus a chimera... a vivid epitome of this town. If the town were to get a coat of arms, the Foreman should be on it.

5.Inquisitor: An equal blend of human and beast. As I understood from esteemed Bos Olgimsky's account, his father had been begotten on a Steppe woman by a bull. He is thus a chimera... a vivid epitome of this town. If the town were to get a coat of arms, the Foreman should be on it.

10.Changeling: Aren't you afraid that I could deceive you?

10.Changeling: Aren't you afraid that I could deceive you?

11.Inquisitor: I'm not. I would learn a great deal more of what I need to know from your deceit than from your honesty, with a few added touches to your own portrait. By the way, let me tell you a little secret about yourself, the first key to unravelling your mystery. You are entirely incapable of deceit.

12.Changeling: Does that mean I'm a Mistress?

13.Inquisitor: The only one around who could be described as a 'mistress' is, at the present moment, me.

12.Changeling: Wrong! I'm capable all right! Don't try to convince me that I'm like that... foreman of yours!

13.Inquisitor: Quiet now... Don't yell. Surprising in a holy person like you, this fervent insistence on your predilection for lying... Falsehood are evil. A stench rising from the abyss of death.

14.Changeling: How am I to get inside the Abattoir?

16.Changeling: So what am I supposed to do?

17.Inquisitor: Find a girl at the Termitary who goes by the name of the Mother Superior. Come up with something to make her let you pass. I suppose you'd handle a small child without any difficulty. However, I wouldn't advise you to try your spells on her. She's Steppe-born, and a special kind of Steppe-born... Not a good idea.

7.Inquisitor: You've mesmerized people before, with quite some success. This really speaks in support of your being... exceptional. Today you're going to test your powers on a monster. You will meet Oyun, the Foreman of the Abattoir.

7.Inquisitor: You've mesmerized people before, with quite some success. This really speaks in support of your being... exceptional. Today you're going to test your powers on a monster. You will meet Oyun, the Foreman of the Abattoir.

8.Changeling: Is he not human?

8.Changeling: Is he not human?

9.Inquisitor: An equal blend of human and beast. As I understood from esteemed Bos Olgimsky's account, his father had been begotten on a Steppe woman by a bull. He is thus a chimera... a vivid epitome of this town. If the town were to get a coat of arms, the Foreman should be on it.

12.Changeling: A threat to what?

14.Changeling: Aren't you afraid that I could deceive you?

15.Inquisitor: I'm not. I would learn a great deal more of what I need to know from your deceit than from your honesty, with a few added touches to your own portrait. By the way, let me tell you a little secret about yourself, the first key to unravelling your mystery. You are entirely incapable of deceit.

8.Changeling: Is he not human?

8.Changeling: Is he not human?

9.Inquisitor: An equal blend of human and beast. As I understood from esteemed Bos Olgimsky's account, his father had been begotten on a Steppe woman by a bull. He is thus a chimera... a vivid epitome of this town. If the town were to get a coat of arms, the Foreman should be on it.

11.Inquisitor: As you can see, the town is small. It's made up of people, not ranks and functions. Fortuitous circumstances had enabled people to create an environment here that everyone could be happy in. But that was entirely due to a miraculous coincidence.

12.Changeling: What coincidence?

12.Changeling: What coincidence?

13.Inquisitor: It's rare that a succession of extraordinary personalities should stand at the helm for five generations. It's even rarer that they should have the love and respect for one another that allows them to carry on the policies of their predecessors. Here, they had grown used to the miracle. And that was their undoing. They wanted to learn to control the miracles. The elder generation had constructed an environment for bringing up the young in the same spirit. They paid for it.

15.Inquisitor: The Law stipulates a harsh punishment for an attempt to capture a miracle. The disease is a means of restoring the balance. A part of the chimeric town must be destroyed, and there is no turning back. The town and the miracle cannot coexist. And I swear I know what the choice should be between them!

19.Inquisitor: The Law stipulates a harsh punishment for an attempt to capture a miracle. The disease is a means of restoring the balance. A part of the chimeric town must be destroyed, and there is no turning back. The town and the miracle cannot coexist. And I swear I know what the choice should be between them!

15.Inquisitor: It's rare that a succession of extraordinary personalities should stand at the helm for five generations. It's even rarer that they should have the love and respect for one another that allows them to carry on the policies of their predecessors. Here, they had grown used to the miracle. And that was their undoing. They wanted to learn to control the miracles. The elder generation had constructed an environment for bringing up the young in the same spirit. They paid for it.

17.Inquisitor: It's rare that a succession of extraordinary personalities should stand at the helm for five generations. 13.Inquisitor: As you can see, the town is small. It's made up of people, not ranks and functions. Fortuitous circumstances had enabled people to create an environment here that everyone could be happy in. But that was entirely due to a miraculous coincidence.

15.Inquisitor: It's rare that a succession of extraordinary personalities should stand at the helm for five generations. It's even rarer that they should have the love and respect for one another that allows them to carry on the policies of their predecessors. Here, they had grown used to the miracle. And that was their undoing. They wanted to learn to control the miracles. The elder generation had constructed an environment for bringing up the young in the same spirit. They paid for it.

15.Inquisitor: Enough! No more of this talk! Why are you so blind? Another obsessed idiot dragging thousands of victims into the very same trap! No, no... enough! Help me destroy the Polyhedron or leave the town at once-or else I'll have you executed!

16.Changeling: But why destroy when everything can be preserved?

16.Changeling: But why destroy when everything can be preserved?

17.Inquisitor: It's the Powers That Be who want to preserve everything; that's the reason there's an epidemic. Who do you think you are? You're no miracle-worker. You are an avatar of the Sand Plague. Do you understand? But instead of acting as an honest instrument of the Law, you have stolen the fate of another.

17.Inquisitor: It's the Powers That Be who want to preserve everything; that's the reason there's an epidemic. Who do you think you are? You're no miracle-worker. 18.Changeling: So that's why I'm a thief?

18.Changeling: So that's why I'm a thief?

19.Inquisitor: That's why you're a thief. You're guilty of the theft of your own fate. You were never to try on this halo. It's as absurd as a hangman playing the miraculous rescuer while the execution is already ongoing.

19.Inquisitor: That's why you're a thief. You're guilty of the theft of your own fate. You were never to try on this halo. It's as absurd as a hangman playing the miraculous rescuer while the execution is already ongoing.

20.Changeling: Now I understand everything...

Your words had also led astray the Bachelor and the Haruspex, to whom I had taken such pains to explain the real state of affairs.

8.Changeling: Really? I didn't know that...

8.Changeling: Really? I didn't know that...

9.Inquisitor: Well, enough idle blather. Since you've already turned up and made a farce out of this Council, decide quickly, and let's be done with it. We're not going to hear anything worthwhile here.
